text: I added a flame graph along the top of my profiler tool to help me zoom into problem areas.  It occurs to me that a super-useful addition here would be to add a second flame graph for the audio thread.  I will think about it.  Mostly I want to clean up the profiler for now so I can move onto integrating the shader/graphics work back into the tool.

text:
I created a new programming language with a friend to see if we could create a compiled language with a simplified bytecode, wrt to traditional languages which allow arbitrary computation that is not guaranteed to halt, that could be automatically parallelized by a VM/runtime (written in Rust :crab:) based on the size and shape of the data. It is still very much in an alpha state, but lmk if you want to learn more or have feedback for us!
• A blog post we wrote about what Turing Completeness prevents <https://alan-lang.org/the-turing-completeness-problem.html> and HN discussion <https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=25006619>
• To learn more about the PL, Alan: <https://github.com/alantech/alan>

attachments.title: alantech/alan
attachments.text: The Alan Programming Language. Contribute to alantech/alan development by creating an account on GitHub.

text:
Hi,

Here's my update about the progress that I made last weekend. Sometime ago I started working on <https://github.com/devhelpr/expressionrunner> , which is library to parse and execute expressions
with support for named variables. This weekend I added support for more operators like & | % << >> and so on.
This allows me to extend my tixy land implementation and it is now more in line with the original. But that's not the end goal offcourse.
I want for example to be able to use this expressionrunner for visibility conditions of form fields (in the form-nodes, which is also a new feature) but also in
my "mini excel"-data-grid node as formulas to reference cells (I've already got the basis covered).

elements.text:
Hi,

Here's my update about the progress that I made last weekend. Sometime ago I started working on

, which is library to parse and execute expressions
with support for named variables. This weekend I added support for more operators like & | % << >> and so on.
This allows me to extend my tixy land implementation and it is now more in line with the original. But that's not the end goal offcourse.
I want for example to be able to use this expressionrunner for visibility conditions of form fields (in the form-nodes, which is also a new feature) but also in
my "mini excel"-data-grid node as formulas to reference cells (I've already got the basis covered).

text: The expressionrunner library also has support to extend it with functions like Math.sin or your own. These can be used from within the expressions. Quite powerful I think

elements.text: The expressionrunner library also has support to extend it with functions like Math.sin or your own. These can be used from within the expressions. Quite powerful I think

text: Some background: The expression is parsed to a tree structure which can be reused to execute the expression multiple times

elements.text: Some background: The expression is parsed to a tree structure which can be reused to execute the expression multiple times

text:
A couple of major milestones this week that video isn't a good fit for:

1. I went back and checked if my old workflow for turning programs into bootable disk images still works, and lo it does. See screenshot.

2. Mu is now _millimeters_ away from being completely memory-safe. While mostly mapping statements 1:1 with machine code instructions. To mark the occasion, here's a summary of the whole language: <https://github.com/akkartik/mu/blob/main/mu.md>. It's not as expressive as C. But it's safe! That means incorrect programs should error out either at compile time or immediately at run time when they try to do something invalid (such as treat memory for one type as another). (Trading off compiler simplicity for some runtime checks is where Mu differs from Rust.)

(Main project page: <https://github.com/akkartik/mu>)

text: I had someone else ask for this. I'll try to investigate. I've never tried it, but it should be quite straightforward for someone who's done this before. Mu is extremely parsimonious in what it requires from the underlying machine.

text:
<http://Lobste.rs|Lobste.rs>: I do share there, usually on periodic weekly "what are you working on" threads. I submitted top posts a few times in the past, but the community seems to have grown enough now that I find "somebody chose to submit this" to be about as strong a signal of feedback as the sum of all comments I get when I do submit. (I also heard some pushback from the moderator about submitting own work in general, which had the effect of accelerating my planned scale-back.)

Here's a map of how I think about my marketing channels: <http://akkartik.name/contact>. Feedback most appreciated.

text:
syscalls: <https://github.com/akkartik/mu/blob/main/init.linux> includes exit, read/write, open/close, creat/unlink/rename, and a few miscellaneous ones. The compiler really only needs read/write/exit.

I've also gotten it running on one other OS, so there's some precedent here: <https://github.com/ozkl/soso>; <https://github.com/akkartik/mu/blob/main/init.soso>

I think I might investigate running it on <https://bellard.org/jslinux/tech.html> relatively soon.

text: Hey man, this is really neat work. I like where you are taking this. Would just love to have a bit more iconic stuff on the left panel and a bit more polish on the design, but it is looking pretty nifty. Good job!

elements.text: Hey man, this is really neat work. I like where you are taking this. Would just love to have a bit more iconic stuff on the left panel and a bit more polish on the design, but it is looking pretty nifty. Good job!
